description: The noun is from Middle English part, from Old English part (“part”) and Old French part (“part”); both from Latin partem, accusative of pars (“piece, portion, share, side, party, faction, role, character, lot, fate, task, lesson, part, member”), from Proto-Indo-European *par-, *per- (“to sell, exchange”). The verb is from Middle English parten, from Old French partir. Akin to portio (“a portion, part”), parare (“to make ready, prepare”). Displaced Middle English del, dele (“part”) (from Old English dǣl (“part, distribution”) > Modern English deal (“portion; amount”)), Middle English dale, dole (“part, portion”) (from Old English dāl (“portion”) > Modern English dole), Middle English sliver (“part, portion”) (from Middle English sliven (“to cut, cleave”), from Old English (tō)slīfan (“to split”)).

entries.meaning: Fractional; partial.
examples: Fred was part owner of the car.

entries.meaning: Partly; partially; fractionally.
A fraction of a whole.
examples: Gaul is divided into three parts.

entries.meaning: A distinct element of something larger.
examples: The parts of a chainsaw include the chain, engine, and handle.

entries.meaning: A group inside a larger group.
Share, especially of a profit.
examples: I want my part of the bounty.

entries.meaning: A unit of relative proportion in a mixture.
examples: The mixture comprises one part sodium hydroxide and ten parts water.

entries.meaning: 3.5 centiliters of one ingredient in a mixed drink.
A section of a document.
examples: Please turn to Part I, Chapter 2.

entries.meaning: A section of land; an area of a country or other territory; region.
(mathematics, dated) A factor.
(US) A room in a public building, especially a courtroom.
Position or role (especially in a play).
examples: We all have a part to play.

entries.meaning: (music) The melody played or sung by a particular instrument, voice, or group of instruments or voices, within a polyphonic piece.
examples: The first violin part in this concerto is very challenging.

entries.meaning: Each of two contrasting sides of an argument, debate etc.; "hand".
examples: He that is not against us is on our part.

entries.meaning: (US) The dividing line formed by combing the hair in different directions.
examples: The part of his hair was slightly to the left.

entries.meaning: (Judaism) In the Hebrew lunisolar calendar, a unit of time equivalent to 3⅓ seconds.
A constituent of character or capacity; quality; faculty; talent; usually in the plural with a collective sense.

verbs.description: part (third-person singular simple present parts, present participle parting, simple past and past participle parted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To leave the company of.
examples: It was strange to him that a father should feel no tenderness at parting with an only son.

entries.meaning: To cut hair with a parting; shed.
(transitive) To divide in two.
(intransitive) To be divided in two or separated; shed.
examples: A rope parts.  His hair parts in the middle.

entries.meaning: (transitive, now rare) To divide up; to share.
(obsolete) To have a part or share; to partake.
To separate or disunite; to remove from contact or contiguity; to sunder.
(obsolete) To hold apart; to stand or intervene between.
To separate by a process of extraction, elimination, or secretion.
(transitive, archaic) To leave; to quit.
(transitive, Internet) To leave (an IRC channel).
examples: He parted the channel saying "SHUTUP!" […] so I queried him, asking if there was something I could do […] maybe talk […] so we did […] since then, I've been seeing him on IRC every day (really can't imagine him not being on IRC anymore actually).
